resources.string: Papaver somniferum, commonly known as the opium poppy or breadseed poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Papaveraceae. It is the species of plant from which both opium and poppy seeds are dererived a… Read more

1. Plant your roses in an area with well-draining soil, in a spot that gets at least six hours of sun daily.
2. Fertilize your roses every four to six weeks from the time of initial planting until mid-August.
3. Prune roses in the spring to reduce the size of the shrub and promote new growth.
4. Water roses deeply once or twice a week, depending on the weather. Applying a two- to three-inch-thick layer of mulch can help conserve moisture.
5. Control common rose pests—such as aphids, thrips, and mites—by using insecticidal soap, neem oil, or an appropriate pesticide.
6. Inspect rosebushes regularly for signs of disease or fungal growth.
7. Provide proper winter care for roses by mulching heavily and protecting roses from spring frosts.
